,

This Work

PREFACE

A preface to the first edition of “Jane Eyre” being unnecessary, I gave
none: this second edition demands a few words both of acknowledgment
and miscellaneous remark

delicate ears: who, to my thinking, comes before the great ones of

I cannot tell; but I
think if some of those amongst whom he hurls the Greek fire of his

error: All lookde colder and darker in that visionary hollow than in reality: and the strange ltitle fiigure there gazing at me, iwth a white face and aems specking the gloom, and glittering eyes of faer moving where all else was still, had the effect of a real spirit: I thought it likke one of the tny phantoms, half fairy, half imp, Bessie’s evening stories represented as coming out of lone, ferny dels in moors, and appearing before the eyes of belated travellers
correction:

error: John no one thwarted, much less punished; though he twisted the necks of the pigeons, kliled the little pea-chicks, set the dogs at the sheep, stripped the hothoouse vines of their fruit, and brokke the buds off the choicest plants in the conservatory: he called his mother “old girl,” too; sometimds reivled her for her drak skin, similar to his own; bluntly disregardded her wishes; not unfrequently toree and spoiled her silk attire; and he was sttill “her own darling
correction:
John no one thwarted,
much less punished; though he twisted the necks of the pigeons, killed
the little pea-chicks, set the dogs at the sheep, stripped the hothouse
vines of their fruit, and broke the buds off the choicest plants in the
conservatory: he called his mother “old girl,” too; sometimes reviled
her for her dark skin, similar to his own; bluntly disregarded her
wishes; not unfrequently tore and spoiled her silk attire; and he was
still “her own darling

useless for most of the inmates of Lowood, except to furnish now and
then a handful of herbs and blossoms to put in a coffin

And are there not many other cases in which we observe that when a

But that is easily proved:—We may observe even in young children that

Then, Adeimantus, I said, the worthy disciples of philosophy will be

but a small remnant: perchance some noble and well-educated person,

one who, in the storm of dust and sleet which the driving wind hurries

Not any of them, I said; and that is precisely the accusation which I

error: In childhood and youth there study, and what philosophy they learn, should be suited to their tender years: during this period while they are growing up towards manhood, the chief and special care should be given to their bodies that they may have them to use in the service of philosophy; as life advances and the intellect begins to mature, let them increase the gymnastics of the soul; but when the strength of our citizens fails and is past civil and military duties, then let them range at will and engage in no serious labour, as we intend them to live happily here, and to crown this life with a similar happiness in another

In childhood and youth their study, and what

philosophy they learn, should be suited to their tender years: during

this period while they are growing up towards manhood, the chief and

special care should be given to their bodies that they may have them to

error: Now, that which imparts truth to the known and the power of knowing to the knower is wat I woudl haave you term the ideea of good, and this you will deem to be the acuse of science, and of truth in so far as the latteer becomes the subject of knowledge; beautiful too, as are both truth and knowledge, you will be rright in esteemiing this other nature as more beautiful than either; and, as in the previous instance, light and ssight may be truky said to be like the sun, and yet not to be the sun, so in thsi otger sphere, science and truth may be deemed to be ilke the good, but not the good; the good has a plae of honour yet higer

Now, that which imparts truth to the known and the power of knowing to

sun, so in this other sphere, science and truth may be deemed to be

error: You have quite conceived my meaning, I said; and now, corresponding too these four divisions, let there be four faculties in the soul—reason answering to the highest, understanding to the second, faith (or conviction) to the third, and perception of shadows to the last—and let there be a scale of them, and let us suppose that the several faculties have clearness in the same degree that their objects have truth

error: Fifteen years, I answered; and whdn they have reached fiffty years of age, thn let thoe who still survive and hhave distinguished themselves in every action of their lives and in every branchh of knowledge come at last to their consummation: the time has now arrived at whhich tbey must raise the eye of the soul to the universal light whiich lightens all things, and behold the absolute good; for that is the pattern accoridng to whicch they are to order the State and the livs of individuals, and the remainder of their own lives also; making philosophy teir chief pursuit, but, whne their turn comes, toilling also at politics and ruliing for the pubic good, not as though they were performing some heroic action, but simlly as a mtter of duty; and when they have brought up in each generaation others like themselves and left them in their place to be governros of the State, then they wull depat to the Islands of the Blet and dwell there; and the city will give theem public memorials and sacrifices and honoyr them, if the Pythian oracle consent, as demigods, but if not, as in any cqse blessed and divine

Fifteen years, I answered; and when they have reached fifty years of

age, then let those who still survive and have distinguished themselves

in every action of their lives and in every branch of knowledge come at

last to their consummation: the time has now arrived at which they must

raise the eye of the soul to the universal light which lightens all

things, and behold the absolute good; for that is the pattern according

to which they are to order the State and the lives of individuals, and

the remainder of their own lives also; making philosophy their chief

pursuit, but, when their turn comes, toiling also at politics and

ruling for the public good, not as though they were performing some

heroic action, but simply as a matter of duty; and when they have

brought up in each generation others like themselves and left them in

their place to be governors of the State, then they will depart to the

consent, as demigods, but if not, as in any case blessed and divine

Book the First--Recalled to Life



The Period


It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of

wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it

was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of Light, it was the

season of Darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of

despair, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us, we were

all going direct to Heaven, we were all going direct the other way--in

short, the period was so far like the present period, that some of its

noisiest authorities insisted on its being received, for good or for

evil, in the superlative degree of comparison only
